snippet: Newtown, Conn., still grieving after the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre, has wrestled with the question of how long is too long to let the public memorials stand.
abstract: Newtown, Conn, is grappling with what to do with scores of well-meaning memorials, attempting answer question of how long to let public displays of sorrow and sympathy stand; at issue is whether such memorials will serve as barriers to moving on, particularly for victims' families.
lead_paragraph: Newtown, Conn., still grieving after the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre, has wrestled with the question of how long is too long to let the public memorials stand.

headline.seo: As Memorials Pile Up, Newtown Struggles to Move On
headline.main: Asking What to Do With Symbols of Grief as Memorials Pile Up
headline.print_headline: Asking What to Do With Symbols of Grief as Memorials Pile Up
